section.title: Glossary of Terms
section.para: Following are terms specific to the Repo Studio environment. They are arranged in alphabetical order.

listitem.para: The machine on which Repo Studio is installed.
The target machine on which repository content is installed.
RPM packages created by Repo Studio during the build process. These packages contain user-specified configuration files and scripts.
For more information on config-rpms, see the chapter in this document. See also the section on config-rpms in the .
An RPM package created by Repo Studio during the build process. This package contains the and YUM configuration for the repository.
For more information on the release-rpm and how to customize its content, see the chapter in this document. See also the section on release-rpm in the .

A deployment repository created during the Repo Studio build process. Provides RPM packages and, optionally, installation images for use during client machine installations and updates. Can be accessed over the network from the .

A file maintained by Repo Studio to track Repo Studio-generated repository input data. The file is created in the same folder as the repository definition, with a filename consisting of the with the .dat file extension. caution.para: Care must be taken not to delete the repository data file. Doing so will cause Repo Studio to regenerate missing information. As a result, installed client machines may fail to download updated RPMs or may report errors when performing RPM GPG key checking.

listitem.para: A file that defines how Repo Studio should build, configure and store a repository. By convention the file uses the .definition extension. The file is in XML format as defined in the .
The rules of syntax for the repository definition. See the separate document at http://www.repostudio.org/documentation/ .
The id for a repository. Corresponds to the global run-time macro %{id}. See the Macros section of the for more information on macros.
The default value is %{name}-%{version}-%{arch}, where these values correspond to the name, version and arch for the repository.

The repository URL is configurable using the remote-url element described in the Deployment Elements chapter of the .

A standard method of reusing content within and across XML documents, sponsored by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). See for complete information on the W3C standard. See also the for general information on using XML Inclusions (XIncludes) within repository definitions.

A YUM plugin provided by Repo Studio that allows synchronizing packages on client machines with packages in the . The plugin is included by default in the , which serves as the mechanism for installing it on client machines.

The plugin establishes the as the master repository, disables all other repositories, and provides a new argument, sync, to YUM. Help for the sync argument is available on client machines using the yum help command. Running yum sync allows YUM to calculate package additions and removals based on packages available in the repository. For more information, see the section on .
